pullRequest.body:
The main result is that the integral (i.e. the expected value) with regard to a
measure derived from a `Pmf` is a sum weighted by the `Pmf`.

It also provides the expected value for specific probability mass functions
(bernoulli so far).

---

- [x] depends on: #6446
- [x] depends on: #6473

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

This looks like it's in pretty good shape, thanks! I just have a few comments regarding generalizing the result, and some cosmetic issues.
Will go away once https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6473 lands

```suggestion
    hasFiniteIntegral_of_bounded (C := (Finset.sup .univ (fun a => ‖f a‖₊) : NNReal)) <| by
      apply ae_of_all μ
      intro x
      rw [← coe_nnnorm (f x)]
      apply NNReal.toReal_le_toReal
      apply Finset.le_sup (Finset.mem_univ x)
```

General guideline for indentation: proofs are indented by 2 characters, and if a statement requires multiple lines, the first such line must be indented by 4 characters so that it's not flush with the proof. (I'm not sure if this is written anywhere, it looks like the style guide is still written for Lean 3...)

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem integrable_of_fintype [Fintype α] [MeasurableSpace α] [MeasurableSingletonClass α]
    [MeasurableSpace β] [PseudoMetrizableSpace β] [SecondCountableTopology β]
    [OpensMeasurableSpace β] (μ : Measure α) [IsFiniteMeasure μ] (f : α → β) :
    Integrable (fun a ↦ f a) μ :=
  ⟨Measurable.aestronglyMeasurable (measurable_of_finite _), hasFiniteIntegral_of_fintype⟩
```
This result is definitely interesting for more than real-valued functions!

```suggestion
variable {α : Type _}

theorem integral_eq_tsum' [MeasurableSpace α] [MeasurableSingletonClass α] (p : Pmf α)
    (f : α → ℝ) (hf : Integrable (fun a ↦ f a) (p.toMeasure)) :
      ∫ a, f a ∂(p.toMeasure) = ∑' a, f a * (p a).toReal := calc
```
Also, I think it would really make sense for the results in this file to be generalized to `f : α → β` for appropriate typeclasses on `β`. This would mean changing the statement to something like `∫ a, f a ∂(p.toMeasure) = ∑' a, (p a).toReal • f a`.
I don't know the type class hierarchy well. Should I try with the type classes you used in the suggestion at `integrable_of_fintype`?

```suggestion
theorem integrable_of_fintype [Fintype α] [MeasurableSpace α] [MeasurableSingletonClass α]
    (μ : Measure α) [IsFiniteMeasure μ] (f : α → ℝ) : Integrable (fun a ↦ f a) μ :=
  ⟨Measurable.aestronglyMeasurable (measurable_of_finite _), hasFiniteIntegral_of_fintype⟩
```

```suggestion
```
This is just a strictly less general version of the previous lemma (in fact it can be proven by `exact integral_eq_tsum' p f hf`), so it can be deleted and we can rename the previous one to `integral_eq_tsum`.
Heh, quite right. not sure where that came from.

```suggestion
theorem integral_eq_sum [Fintype α]
  (p : Pmf α) (f : α → E) :
    ∫ a, f a ∂(p.toMeasure) = ∑ a, (p a).toReal • f a := by
```
This should also be true, I guess we just need the right generalization of `integrable_of_fintype`.

```suggestion
/-- Simple function defined on an finite type. -/
def ofFintype [Fintype α] [MeasurableSingletonClass α] (f : α → β) : α →ₛ β where
```

```suggestion
/-- Simple function defined on a finite type. -/
```
